titleStmt.title: Possible Futures for the Psychological Network Approach: Agenda for Clinical Scientists

affiliation.orgName: National Center of Neurology and Psychiatry * Correspondence

analytic.title: Possible Futures for the Psychological Network Approach: Agenda for Clinical Scientists

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: The psychological network approach, which conceptualizes mental disorders as complex systems and provides a statistical toolbox to estimate symptom networks, has evoked innovations in psychopathology research. This perspective paper discusses how to implement this approach in real-world clinical settings, emphasizing that clinical scientists should motivate clinicians and clients to utilize it. To promote the clinical use of the psychological network approach, we provide the following five steps clinical scientists should undertake: 1) provide clinicians and clients with the necessary background knowledge, 2) encourage clinicians to use the narrative network models, 3) provide clinicians with user-friendly software to conduct empirical network analyses, 4) explore clients' experiences during the pilot trials using the psychological network approach, and 5) develop guidelines for interventions using the psychological network approach through the collaboration of clinical scientists, clinicians, and clients. We close the paper by discussing the importance of bridging the academic field and clinical settings, in the hopes that other clinical scientists will participate in the discussion of possible futures for the psychological network approach.

div.head: Rapid development of the psychological network approach within the academic field
div.p: Over the past two decades, the psychological network approach, also known as network psychometrics, has evoked conceptual and methodological innovations in psychopathology research (Borsboom, 2017;Borsboom & Cramer, 2013;Borsboom et al., 2011;Jones et al., 2017;Robinaugh et al., 2020). 1 This approach abandons the latent disease or common cause models for mental disorders (e.g., assuming that the entity called major depressive disorder causes individual symptoms), which have been dominant in previous clinical psychological research relying on factor analytic or structural equation modeling approaches. Rather, this approach conceptualizes these disorders as complex systems (i.e., networks) sustained by interactions between individual symptoms (Borsboom & Cramer, 2013;Borsboom et al., 2019). It also provides a statistical toolbox with which to estimate both within-and between-person network structures using empirical quantitative datasets, typically comprising clients' self-reports of their symptoms (Robinaugh et al., 2020). These empirical psychological networks, in turn, imply clinical hypotheses to disrupt the networks efficiently (e.g., decreasing the most central symptom to quickly deactivate the entire network of depression; Borsboom & Cramer, 2013;Hofmann et al., 2016). They also enable clinical scientists 2 to detect early warning signals of sudden changes in given mental disorders (Dablander et al., 2023;Fried et al., 2017). Such perspectives and methodologies have attracted both psychometricians and clinical scientists, and the number of academic articles using the psychological network approach has exponentially increased. A systematic review by Robinaugh et al. (2020) revealed that 363 articles were published between 2008 to 2018 and that 60% of articles were published in the last two years of that range. This increased attention to the psychological network approach led to the publication of a special issue of Psychometrika entitled "Network Psychometrics in Action" (Marsman & Rhemtulla, 2022) and a comprehensive textbook (Isvoranu et al., 2022). 1 Considering that the psychological network approach has been discussed and used mostly in clinical psychology and psychiatry (Borsboom et al., 2022;Robinaugh et al., 2020) and that our focus is on those research areas, we used the phrase "the psychological network approach" to indicate "the psychological network approach used in clinical psychology and psychiatry" for the sake of readability. However, it should be noted that the approach itself can be applied to the other subfields of psychological science, including social (Dalege et al., 2016;Dalege & van der Maas, 2020) and personality psychology (Cramer et al., 2012). 2 In recent years, many clinical psychology and psychiatry researchers have begun to define their discipline as "clinical science" (e.g., the Journal of Abnormal Psychology changed its title to the Journal of Psychopathology and Clinical Science in January 2022;MacDonald et al., 2021). This term reflects how modern clinical psychology employs scientific methodologies developed in the other subfields within psychological science (e.g., psychometrics) and works in collaboration with the other mental health related disciplines (e.g., psychiatry) to tackle the complex phenomena of psychopathology (see also Association for Psychological Science, 2020). Throughout this paper, we use the term "clinical scientists" to indicate the clinical science researchers who satisfy the following requirements: i) majoring primarily in clinical psychology, psychiatry, or the other mental health related disciplines; ii) using modern psychological science methodologies; iii) regularly working on theoretical or empirical research focused on psychopathology and other mental health related issues; and iv) willing to communicate with clinicians and clients in clinical settings.

As Borsboom (2022) summarized, the core of the psychological network approach is its conceptualization of mental disorders and related psychological constructs as complex systems instead of latent disease entities. This so-called network thinking (or systems thinking 3 ) enables clinicians (i.e., practitioners of psychotherapies) to avoid getting stuck in the traditional protocol-for-syndrome approach, in which they deliver interventions based on a predefined protocol designed for each predefined diagnostic category. As is evident by the heterogeneity (Fried & Nesse, 2015) and comorbidity (Beekman et al., 2000) of mental disorders, such protocol-for-syndrome approach does not work well for real complex clinical cases. By using the network conceptualization instead, clinicians can focus on interplays between individual symptoms to capture a unique complex pattern within each client. These individualized case formulations will help clinicians tailor their therapies according to the clients' unique patterns and efficiently intervene in the central symptoms in their network structures. This paradigm shift from latent disease to network modeling has inspired clinical scientists, and novel therapy frameworks including process-based therapy (PBT; Hayes et al., 2020;Hofmann et al., 2021) detailed later has been proposed to apply network thinking into mental health care and promote individualized therapies. As suggested by Hofmann et al. (2020), these therapy frameworks can incorporate the aforementioned statistical toolbox to understand the individualized networks structures and help predict and control their changes. Such combinations potentially innovate clinical therapies and move the entire field forward to tackle more intensively the following classic but unresolved core questions of clinical sciences: "What treatment, by whom, is most effective for this individual with that specific problem, under which set of circumstances, and how does it come about?" (Paul, 1969, p. 44).

Inspired by the network thinking, various statistical models have been developed to estimate and visualize the network structures of psychometric variables. The most popular include the Gaussian Epskamp, Waldorp, et al., 2018) and mixed (Haslbeck & Waldorp, 2020) graphical models using cross-sectional data, and the graphical vector autoregressive (GVAR; Epskamp, van Borkulo, et al., 2018;Epskamp, Waldorp, et al., 2018;Wild et al., 2010) model using time series data. For illustration purposes, we reprinted a visualization of the GVAR model estimated by Marian and Sava (2023) as an example set of network structures (Figure 1). The two networks in Figure 1 were estimated from N = 111 time series data including items of depressive symptoms (red nodes) and negative automatic thoughts (blue nodes). In the network psychometrics, statistical relationships between variables are visualized as either directed or undirected edges. In the case of Figure 1, temporal and contemporaneous networks were estimated using the GVAR model, and we can quickly 3 Notably, the phrase "systems thinking" here has its roots not in the systems or systemic approach of integrative family therapy (Burnham, 2002;Gunn et al., 2015;Minuchin, 1985) but in the network sciences (Barabási, 2016), which are detailed later in this paper. The systems or systemic approach focuses on psychodynamic interplays between specific persons (e.g., family members) to examine how to intervene a holistic between-person system (e.g., a family), and is not necessarily concerned with empirical data analyses. By contrast, the systems thinking used in the psychological network approach investigates how the dynamic interplays between components (e.g., symptoms) sustain some systems (e.g., mental disorders) and emphasizes the combined use with empirical data analyses. Although systems thinking and the subsequent data analyses can be applied to examine interpersonal dynamics (e.g., Bringmann et al., 2018), they are typically used to investigate intrapersonal (i.e., within an individual or an average person) interplays of psychometric variables. comprehend the signs (i.e., green and red edges represent positive and negative statistical relationships, respectively) and strengths (i.e., thickness of the edges) of the lag-1 autoregression and cross-lag effects (i.e., directed edges in the left panel) and those of partial correlations within the same time window (i.e., undirected edges in the right panel). From cross-sectional data, on the other hand, partial correlations between variables are visualized as a network that looks similar to the right panel of Figure 1. Moreover, the GVAR model can be used in combination with N = 1 intensive time series data collected by experience sampling methods (Myin-Germeys et al., 2018) to visualize personalized temporal and contemporaneous networks. (Marian & Sava, 2023, p. 713, Figure 3) Note. Red and blue nodes represent depressive symptoms and negative automatic thoughts, respectively. The directed edges in the left panel visualize significant lag-1 autoregression and cross-lag effects, and the undirected edges in the right panel represent significant partial correlations within the same time window. Green and red edges represent positive and negative statistical effects, respectively. The thickness of the edges reflects the strength of the effects. From "Identifying central negative thoughts using experience sampling and network analysis," by Ş. Marian and F. A. Sava, 2023, Cognitive Therapy and Research, 47, p. 713 (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10608-023-10400-w). Reprinted under the terms of the Creative Commons CC BY 4.0 license.

As discussed, these networks estimated from empirical data have considerable potentials to facilitate case formulations 4 in cognitive behavioral therapies (Kuyken et al., 2009;Persons, 2012;Persons & Talbot, 2019). In contrast to the standard case formulations based on clients' narratives and the evidence from traditional latent disease conceptualizations, empirical networks provide high-resolution pictures of mental disorders sustained by interplaying components and enable clinicians and clients to detect characteristic links (e.g., strong edges) in the network structures. Furthermore, summary indices can be calculated to describe both local and global properties of the estimated network structures. Local network properties can be summarized by centrality indices (Haslbeck et al., 2021;Opsahl et al., 2010;Robinaugh et al., 2016), which quantify how likely it is that each node works as a hub in the network. Global network properties can be summarized as connectivity or density metrices (Cramer et al., 2016;van Borkulo et al., 2015), which quantify how vulnerable the networks are to perturbations. Of course, empirical network models do not reveal true causal structures of mental disorders. As is the case with all statistical models, they always include measurement errors, contain certain artifacts, and can only establish Granger causality (i.e., temporal predictions between variables; Burger, Hoekstra, et al., 2022;Granger, 1969) at best. Nevertheless, the statistical relationships found in network analyses possibly lead to unique clinical hypotheses that cannot be generated only by standard case formulations. Moreover, network analyses can be helpful in discussing how psychological factors affect psychopathological symptoms in detail. For instance, by looking at the temporal network in Figure 1 (left panel), we can broaden the established relationship between negative automatic thoughts and depressive symptoms (Beck, 1995;Schniering & Rapee, 2004) by discussing which thoughts affect which symptoms strongly. Similarly, detailed component-tocomponent investigations of the relationship between inflated responsibility and obsessive-compulsive symptoms (Pozza & Dèttore, 2014;Sugiura & Fisak, 2019) can be achieved by conducting empirical network analyses.

To achieve the ultimate goal of innovating clinical therapies in future by facilitating idiographic case formulations and tailored interventions, the psychological network approach has become widespread within the academic field of clinical psychological science as an initial step. Owing to the tireless efforts of the PsychoSystems group at the University of Amsterdam, staffed primarily by sophisticated network psychometricians, clinical scientists can now easily access a comprehensive textbook (Isvoranu et al., 2022) and various packages to conduct network analyses via the R statistical environment (Burger et al., 2023;. They can also learn the latest theories and methodologies directly from network psychometricians (e.g., Psychological Networks Amsterdam Summer/Winter Schools; https://osf.io/m9yz4/). To summarize, the psychological network approach has spent most of its infancy period within academia building solid theoretical and methodological foundations to apply in clinical settings. Considering that several proof-of-principle studies (Bak et al., 2016;Frumkin et al., 2021;Kroeze et al., 2017;Lutz et al., 2018;Rubel et al., 2018;Wichers et al., 2016) indicated the clinical utility of empirical network analyses, it seems fair to assume that applications of the psychological network approach will greatly benefit clinical practices. For instance, N = 1 proof-of-principle studies showed that empirical network models increase the client's insight into their symptom pattern (Kroeze et al., 2017). Further, changes in network density over time successfully reflected changes in the severity of psychosis (Bak et al., 2016) and depression (Wichers et al., 2016). Moreover, small sample studies (N < 60) showed that personalized intervention recommendations were automatically identified by network analyses (Rubel et al., 2018) and that empirical networks at baseline successfully captured individualized patterns of symptom interplays (Frumkin et al., 2021) and predicted treatment dropout (Lutz et al., 2018). It is hoped that these findings will be translated into more large-scale clinical trials so that greater benefits of the clinical use of the psychological network approach will be revealed.

div.head: Agenda for clinical scientists using the psychological network approach:
div.p: The need to bridge the academic field and clinical settings

This perspective paper discusses what clinical scientists should do next, regarding the psychological network approach. Network psychometricians have set research agendas to sophisticate the theoretical and methodological foundations of this approach (Borsboom, 2022;Robinaugh et al., 2020), and clinical scientists have begun to point out the need to develop statistical models and indices that are readily applicable in clinical therapies (Bringmann, 2021;Bringmann et al., 2022). Compared to these hot discussions in the academic field, however, discussion of how to deliver the psychological network approach in clinical settings is currently scarce. Although many theoretical papers have discussed that the psychological network approach potentially innovate clinical practices (e.g., Borsboom, 2022;Borsboom & Cramer, 2013;Hofmann et al., 2020), very few pilot trials using the approach have been conducted so far, except for several studies with a single participant (Bak et al., 2016;Kroeze et al., 2017;Wichers et al., 2016) or with a small sample size (Frumkin et al., 2021;Lutz et al., 2018;Rubel et al., 2018). There are currently no roadmaps for i) how to make both clinicians and clients aware of the values of the psychological network approach, ii) what kinds of tools and devices should be prepared to amplify clinicians' expectancy that they can use the approach, and iii) how to establish the evidence of the clinical utility of the approach through pilot trials and larger interventional studies. No novel approach can evoke innovations in real-world settings and establish its evidence without users' participation. Researchers of the psychological network approach should struggle to motivate clinicians and clients to utilize the approach in the near future, as well as revise their methodologies in the academic field.

We believe clinical scientists occupy a position that bridges the academic field with real-world clinical settings (see Figure 2). They should discuss how to start the promotion of the psychological network approach within the clinical setting. Additionally, strategies should be prepared to make clinicians and clients aware of the values regarding the approach and increase their expectancy to utilize it. This paper, written by a team of clinical scientists, provides five steps (for a summary, see Figure 2) to achieve this future agenda. We intend to demonstrate directions that clinical scientists should move forward with rather than to specify the exact contents and timescale for each step. Although these five steps mainly follow a step-up manner (e.g., it makes no sense to encourage clinicians to the narrative network models [Step 2], unless they understand the necessary background knowledge of the psychological network approach for the first time [Step 1]), but they also allow occasional stepping back if necessary (e.g., clinical scientists might sometimes revise the mobile apps they developed [Step 3], based on the feedbacks from the clients participated in the pilot trials [Step 4]). We believe that all the five steps should be undertaken for the implementation, and some readers might notice the necessity of adding more steps or dividing an existing step into multiple ones. In short, these steps are designed as a primer for researchers to begin the discussion on how to implement the psychological network approach.

div.head: Step 1: Provide clinicians and clients with the necessary background knowledge
div.p: First, clinical scientists should provide clinicians and clients with the background knowledge required to understand the values of the psychological network approach. This knowledge includes the fact that Figure 2 Clinical Scientists as a Bridge Node and Five Steps that They Should Undertake to Bridge the Academic Field and Clinical Settings Note. The interrelationships between network psychometricians, clinical scientists, clinicians, and clients are visualized as a network. current clinical psychology and psychiatry have begun to face the heterogeneity and complexity of mental disorders (Fried & Nesse, 2015), which may have been recognized among clinicians and clients for a long time but overlooked in traditional diagnosis systems and the protocol-for-syndrome approach. Clinicians and clients should be taught that current clinical psychology and psychiatry are seeking to develop targeted precision therapies (Boschloo et al., 2019;Ng & Weisz, 2016), which drive the idea of capturing individual symptom networks and tailor network-based clinical hypotheses.

In addition to the current directions in clinical sciences, the general utility of network sciences should be explained to clinicians and clients. As summarized by Barabási (2016), network scientists have developed sophisticated theories and methodologies for decades and have applied their network thinking (i.e., ways of thinking that regard empirical phenomena as complex interplays between individual components) to various academic disciplines, including physics, economics, sociology, neurophysiology, and infectious disease medicine. The psychological network approach is an application of network sciences in the field of psychology, and the utility of the approach comes partly from the utility of network sciences themselves. Clinicians and clients might benefit from knowing how network sciences help understand and intervene in real-world complex systems (e.g., identifying a hub person in a given social network, tracing an infected person's contact to prevent an epidemic). Then, they will become accustomed to network thinking in general and gradually become convinced of the values of the psychological network approach. This process seems important not only for clinicians who try to tailor their therapies but also for clients who internalize stigma stemming from diagnostic labels. Instead of suffering from self-stigma (for theoretical details of self-stigma, see Corrigan & Watson, 2002) and recklessly receiving protocol-based therapies, clients can use network thinking to view their own problems as a sequence of symptoms and events and to gradually understand what processes are going on within themselves.

div.head: Step 2: Encourage clinicians to use the narrative network models
div.p: After clinicians and clients become aware of the value of the psychological network approach, we need to strategically amplify clinicians' expectancy that they can use it. Given the limited time and scarcity of expert data analysts in many clinical settings, it seems unrealistic to expect clinicians to estimate empirical networks and fully use the psychological network approach from the beginning. Instead, clinicians should be encouraged to use narrative network models at first. Clinicians routinely collect a lot of narrative information from their clients. Thus, it might be easy for them to draw network diagrams from these narratives.

Recently developed PBT (Hayes et al., 2020;Hofmann et al., 2021) will guide clinicians in using narrative network models. PBT is a novel framework embracing different psychotherapeutic orientations (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy, psychodynamics, and acceptance and commitment therapy), which regards each client as a unique complex system instead of forcibly fitting clients into predefined diagnostic categories. It provides clinicians: i) a step-by-step guide with which to draw narrative network models for their clients; ii) the extended evolutionary meta-model that indicates what kinds of information should be included in each narrative network; iii) ideas taken from the network sciences that can be useful for case management (e.g., identifying feedback loops in a narrative network, detecting critical speeding-up in a given system); and iv) opportunities to incorporate empirical data analyses, including network analyses, into their therapies. Clinicians using PBT will be readily accustomed to applying network thinking in their therapies, and some of them will become interested in estimating empirical networks.

Of note, narrative network models can be drawn in the PBT framework through a series of simple conversations between clinicians and clients. Suppose that a client claims he or she feels depressed frequently and cannot sleep well. In that case, two nodes labeled "feeling depressed" and "cannot sleep well" could be written down. Then, a clinician could ask the client whether the relationship between these two nodes is unidirectional or bidirectional. If the client answers, "I always feel depressed after poor sleep, but the opposite is not true," then an arrow from "cannot sleep well" to "feeling depressed" would be drawn (see Figure 3). To summarize, narrative network models are visualizations of naïve inferences of relationships between events that clients experience. In reality, clients suffer many more negative events; thus, the entire narrative networks become much more complex than the two-node network depicted in Figure 2. Such complex networks can be drawn by cumulating the simple conversations noted above.

div.head: Step3: Provide clinicians with user-friendly software to conduct empirical network analyses
div.p: To fully motivate clinicians interested in empirical network analyses, user-friendly software for estimating and displaying empirical networks need to be developed. Although several existing R packages, including the qgraph , psychonetrics (Epskamp et al., 2022), mgm (Haslbeck & Waldorp, 2020), graphicalVAR (Epskamp, 2023), and mlVAR (Epskamp et al., 2023) packages, enable such estimations, most inexperienced clinicians with regard to programming will be disinclined to use such character user interface (CUI)-based analytical packages by themselves at first. If software with graphical user interfaces (GUIs) or user-friendly interactive features become available, clinicians can easily estimate empirical networks without needing to write any syntax. They can then show the resulting networks to their clients, explaining the characteristics of the entire network structures (e.g., network density), as well as roles of individual nodes (e.g., which nodes seem most central). They will also be able to discuss intervention strategies (e.g., which nodes should be targeted) together. Such intensive communications using empirical networks will provide unique insights that cannot be detected with only narrative-based inferences. Further, they will facilitate collaborative clinical decision-making between clinicians and clients.

We are aware that several free software and personal computer tools partly satisfy the need for user-friendly features. For example, recent versions of the JASP software enable GUI-based estimations of empirical networks and calculations of centrality indices (see https://jaspstats.org/2018/03/20/perform-network-analysis-jasp/). Another example is the ESMvis Shiny app developed by Bringmann et al. (2021), which visualizes dynamic fluctuations in item scores measured by the experience sampling method (ESM) to enrich personalized feedback in clinical settings. Newly developed software to enable both GUI-based estimations of personalized networks and the visualization of dynamic changes in network structures will certainly be helpful for clinicians who seek to generate tailored clinical hypotheses based on the psychological network approach. Moreover, any software that also has features roughly simulating the impact of activating and deactivating some nodes will greatly facilitate explanations of treatment processes and collaborative clinical decision-making between clinicians and clients.

The GUI-based user-friendly software will hopefully serve as a steppingstone to enhance clinicians' interest in using CUI-based R packages for network estimations by themselves. Psychological network analysis methodology continues to develop rapidly (see Robinaugh et al., 2020 for a review), and novel analyses are usually provided through R packages. Considering that current psychological science promotes open science practices (Bauer, 2022;Nosek et al., 2015) many sample codes are available at online platforms such as the Open Science Framework (https://osf.io/) for conducting network analyses. Therefore, it is possible for clinicians to develop their own network analysis skills via R. Although it is not necessary for every clinician to catch up with newer R packages to make network estimations, experiences in using CUI-based software will lead to more successful collaborations with clinical scientists who are on the frontiers of the psychological network approach.

Step 4: Explore clients' experiences during the pilot trials using the psychological network approach If clinicians are confident that they can utilize empirical networks in clinical settings, it will be easier to conduct pilot trials of therapies using the psychological network approach. Such pilot trials should fully explore the clients' experiences during therapy. Although several N=1 (Bak et al., 2016;Kroeze et al., 2017;Wichers et al., 2016) and small sample (Frumkin et al., 2021) pilot trials have been conducted to evaluate the utility of personalized networks in clinical settings, these studies mainly discussed the characteristics of the estimated networks from the researchers' viewpoints and did not intensively explore clients' experiences during the sessions. For example, Frumkin et al. (2021) used only self-report items of attitudes toward ESM and personalized networks and did not report clients' narratives of why they were satisfied or dissatisfied with those methodologies. Future pilot trials, therefore, should conduct intensive qualitative interviews with clients, as Pain et al. (2008) and Redhead et al. (2015) did in the cognitive behavior therapy case formulation. Clients may find both advantages and disadvantages of the psychological network approach that clinical scientists and clinicians do not recognize. Thus, their feedback is indispensable to revise the procedures for the clinical use of empirical networks.

Moreover, their feedback can be clues to discuss what is the "evidence" of the clinical utility of the psychological network approach. Since this approach discards traditional latent disease conceptualizations (e.g., assuming that symptoms are caused by the entity called major depressive disorder), investigations of the clinical utility of the approach cannot go as straightforward as traditional assessments of the effectiveness of clinical therapies (e.g., examining whether a total score of depression symptom items is decreased after the intervention). The effectiveness of network-based interventions possibly includes decreasing central symptoms in a psychopathology network, reducing the time required to achieve a certain level of improvement in overall symptoms, better predictability of relapse patterns, and so forth. It is, therefore, important to explore in what sense participants in clinical trials feel good or bad about the psychological network approach. Such considerations can inform the guidelines for interventions (Step 5) about what kind of criteria should be used to evaluate the effectiveness of the network-based interventions.

It should also be noted that clients' experiences may differ according to the purpose of the clinical use of psychological networks. Although Frumkin et al. (2021) and Kroeze et al. (2017) estimated personalized networks from the data collected during the baseline assessment periods to facilitate collaborative clinical decision-making before the interventions, there is another option to continue data collection aimed at monitoring changes in network structures during therapy and switching intervention plans if needed. Both options may have pros and cons for clients. Therefore, pilot trials need to clarify their purposes for using the psychological network approach and carefully explore clients' experiences during the sessions. Such careful investigations will guide the purposive revisions of tools, including data analysis software (i.e., turning backward to Step 3), and the development of detailed guidelines for the clinical use of the psychological network approach (i.e., moving forward to Step 5).

Clients' experiences during the pilot trials may also clarify which subpopulations prefer the psychological network approach and/or can utilize it appropriately. Although we assume many clients can construct narrative networks easily through a series of simple causal inferences between events (see Step 2 for details), some clients possibly show less interest in the network approach in the first place and may prefer using only simple diagnostic labels to describe their problems. It is also concerned that some clients may jump to causal interpretations of the edges appearing in the empirical networks, as discussed by Rimpler et al. (2024). Considering that even the directed edges in temporal networks estimated from time series data can indicate Granger causality at best (Burger, Hoekstra, et al., 2022;Granger, 1969), it is possible that clients who cannot afford to make careful interpretations of the edges due to some uncontrollable reasons (e.g., time restriction, high impulsivity) are not well-suited to the psychological network approach. As we do not have any strong assumptions regarding which subpopulations can or cannot utilize the psychological network approach appropriately, some exclusion or inclusion criteria for network-based interventions need to be established by analyzing clients' experiences.

Step 5: Develop the guidelines for interventions using the psychological network approach through the collaborations of clinical scientists, clinicians, and clients Finally, guidelines for interventions using the psychological network approach should be developed. These guidelines should include both clinical and reporting ones to achieve clinical and academic excellence. Clinical guidelines will increase clinicians' expectancies regarding their ability to use the psychological network approach and enable them to collect quantitative data from their clients efficiently and appropriately. Reporting guidelines will inform clinical scientists how to analyze clinical quantitative data and what kind of information should be reported in academic papers. Wellorganized analyses and their reports will inspire other clinicians to begin using the psychological network approach. Moreover, the newly collected data will motivate clinical scientists to improve the quality of their analyses and reports. To summarize, we expect clinical and reporting guidelines to form a virtuous circle with which to increase the value of the entire psychological network approach.

We are aware that a reporting guideline for cross-sectional network analyses has been established from the viewpoint of network psychometricians (Burger et al., 2023) and anticipate similar reporting guidelines will be developed for time-series and personalized network analyses. Clinical scientists' tasks are, therefore, to lead the development of clinical guidelines and add clinical views to the reporting guidelines developed by network psychometricians. In undertaking these tasks, clinical scientists should collaborate with clinicians and clients to ensure the guidelines' clinical utility. As Premachandra and Lewis (2022) have recently warned, interventional studies in the psychological sciences often fail to report all the information necessary to implement the findings into practice. The participation of stakeholders (i.e., clinicians and clients) of network-based therapies in the development and revision of clinical and reporting guidelines will certainly decrease the information gaps noted by Premachandra and Lewis (2022). Considering that there are two main options (i.e., pre-intervention assessments or continuous monitoring during the interventions) regarding the clinical use of the psychological network approach, it will be a hard work for clinical scientists to facilitate collaboration with clinicians and clients to develop and revise all the necessary guidelines. Given that the current psychological network approach has not yet reached a consensus on how to interpret the results from empirical network analyses (e.g., topology of networks, centrality indexes), clinical scientists should conduct many theoretical and empirical studies in collaboration with network psychometricians to ensure the quality of such guidelines. We believe, however, such hard collaborative work is worthy to undertake if clinical scientists really want to implement the psychological network approach in clinical settings and increase its clinical value.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Thanks to tireless collaborations between network psychometricians and clinical scientists, the psychological network approach has rapidly increased its influence in the academic field. To realize the potential of this approach to evoke innovations in real-world psychotherapies, clinical scientists have a lot of work to do to bridge the academic field and clinical settings. This perspective article has provided five necessary steps with which clinical scientists can implement the psychological network approach in clinical settings, with an emphasis on motivating clinicians and clients to utilize it. We hope other clinical scientists will use our agenda as a general pointer for clinical implementation and participate in the discussion of possible futures for the psychological network approach to make it really useful for clinicians and clients.

figure.head: Figure 1
figure.figDesc: Temporal and Contemporaneous Networks (N = 111) of Depressive Symptoms and Negative Automatic Thoughts

figure.head: Figure 3
figure.figDesc: An Example Narrative Network Model with Two Nodes Note. The nodes (i.e., squares) represent events that are mentioned in a client's narrative. A directed edge (i.e., an arrow) represents the client's inference of a relationship between the two nodes.

body.note: The phrase "case formulations" here is used as an umbrella term to include the cognitive therapy case formulation (or conceptualization) approach rooted in the Beck Case Conceptualization Diagram(Beck, 1995) and the behavioral therapy functional analyses(Haynes & O'Brien, 1990) which are rooted inSkinner's (1953) behaviorism.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: We thank Hiroko Nozaki (https://hirokonozaki.tumblr.com/) for elaborating Figure 1 and Editage by Cactus Communications Inc. (https://www.editage.jp/) for English language editing.

div.head: Conflict of Interest
div.p: The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest.

div.p: Conceived and designed the paper: JK. Analysed and interpreted the literature: JK. Drafted the manuscript: JK. Contributed significantly to the content of the manuscript: All authors. Critically revised the manuscript: DS, YK, YT, SN, and MI. Final writing and full approval of the manuscript: All authors.
